result.content:
# Technical Knowledge · Transponder ## Transponder ### Radar basics If you've ever flown in real life or on VATSIM, then you've probably come across the transponder and entered 4 digits. But why is all this necessary? There are two types of radar for monitoring air traffic: · Primary radar: These are the huge, rotating radar antennas that detect so-called primary targets. According to a simple physical principle, the radar emits pulses that are reflected by aircraft. The radar can calculate the distance to the detected target based on the time between transmitting the pulse and receiving the reflection. The transponder therefore plays no role for this type of radar. · Secondary radar: Secondary radar is used to obtain information about the aircraft's callsign and altitude in addition to its position. This is based on a question-and-answer principle. The radar antenna triggers the transponder via a signal, which then sends the code and altitude back to the ground station. In the picture you can see the Deister radar system of German air traffic control (Deutsche Flugsicherung - DFS). The large curved part is the primary antenna, the small and flat area at the top is the secondary radar antenna. ### Transponder code and correlation The pilot can enter a four-digit transponder code into their transponder. The transponder has the digits 0-7 available for each digit. The system is therefore based on an octal code and offers 4096 different possibilities for a transponder code. Together with the clearance from air traffic control, the pilot receives the code to be set in the transponder. But why do we see a callsign on the radar and not a four-digit number? Well, as soon as the controller has assigned the transponder code on the ground, this code is stored in the flight plan of this specific aircraft. As an example, let's assume that flight DLH414 is assigned the code 2301. If flight DLH414 now takes off, it emits code 2301 and is thus detected by a secondary radar. The secondary radar then sends the position, altitude and code 2301 to the air traffic control center. The radar system then checks the flight plan database and recognizes that code 2301 belongs to flight DLH414. The radar system therefore displays the callsign DLH414 and the corr ude to the controllers at the reported DLH98AD H A42 4 25 position, as shown in the following image. Further information on the transponder can be found here. ### Mode S As technology progressed, new transponders were introduced that were able to transmit many other parameters in addition to the altitude and the code, such as speed, heading, etc. With these transponders, which are called Mode S (Mode Sierra) transponders, the callsign is no longer transmitted via a four-digit code. Instead, the callsign is transmitted directly from the transponder to the secondary radar without the detour via code. Therefore, these flights no longer necessarily need different codes and usually receive Squawk 1000. Mode S is now mandatory in Germany. Further information on Mode S can be found here. ### Special codes Fixed transponder codes are defined for certain flights in Germany. There are also international codes in the event of air emergencies.
Squawk code Usage
0020 Helicopter rescue flights
0023 Federal police operational flights
0024 Night low flying system military flights conducting terrain following flights
0025 Drop aircraft for parachutists
0027 Aerobatic flights
0030 Photogrammetric surveying flights
Squawk code Usage
0031 „Open Skies“ flights
0032 VFR flights by civil aircraft in the identification zone (border between Germany, Poland and the Czech Republic)
0033 VFR flights by military aircraft between GND and FL 100
0034 Search And Rescue missions (SAR)
0035 VFR / IFR flight rule changes
0036 Police operational flights
0037 Police operational flights with residual light amplifier
1000 Mode S transponder code
2000 Military flights in the Night low flying system
7000 VFR flights by civil aircraft (standard VFR code)
7500 Hijacking (prohibited on VATSIM)
7600 Radio failure
7700 Emergency

lines.content: Technical
Knowledge
· Transponder
Transponder
Radar basics
If you've ever flown in real life or on VATSIM, then you've probably come across the transponder
and entered 4 digits. But why is all this necessary?
There are two types of radar for monitoring air traffic:
· Primary radar: These are the huge, rotating radar antennas that detect so-called
primary targets. According to a simple physical principle, the radar emits pulses that are
reflected by aircraft. The radar can calculate the distance to the detected target based on
the time between transmitting the pulse and receiving the reflection. The transponder
therefore plays no role for this type of radar.
· Secondary radar: Secondary radar is used to obtain information about the aircraft's
callsign and altitude in addition to its position. This is based on a question-and-answer
principle. The radar antenna triggers the transponder via a signal, which then sends the
code and altitude back to the ground station.
In the picture you can see the Deister radar system of German air traffic control (Deutsche
Flugsicherung - DFS). The large curved part is the primary antenna, the small and flat area at the
top is the secondary radar antenna.
Transponder code and correlation
The pilot can enter a four-digit transponder code into their transponder. The transponder has the
digits 0-7 available for each digit. The system is therefore based on an octal code and offers 4096
different possibilities for a transponder code. Together with the clearance from air traffic control,
the pilot receives the code to be set in the transponder. But why do we see a callsign on the radar
and not a four-digit number? Well, as soon as the controller has assigned the transponder code on
the ground, this code is stored in the flight plan of this specific aircraft. As an example, let's
assume that flight DLH414 is assigned the code 2301. If flight DLH414 now takes off, it emits code
2301 and is thus detected by a secondary radar. The secondary radar then sends the position,
altitude and code 2301 to the air traffic control center. The radar system then checks the flight
plan database and recognizes that code 2301 belongs to flight DLH414. The radar system therefore
displays the callsign DLH414 and the corr
ude to the controllers at the reported
DLH98AD H
position, as shown in the following image.
Further information on the transponder can be found here.
Mode S
As technology progressed, new transponders were introduced that were able to transmit many
other parameters in addition to the altitude and the code, such as speed, heading, etc. With these
transponders, which are called Mode S (Mode Sierra) transponders, the callsign is no longer
transmitted via a four-digit code. Instead, the callsign is transmitted directly from the transponder
to the secondary radar without the detour via code. Therefore, these flights no longer necessarily
need different codes and usually receive Squawk 1000.
Mode S is now mandatory in Germany.
Further information on Mode S can be found here.
Special codes
Fixed transponder codes are defined for certain flights in Germany. There are also international
codes in the event of air emergencies.
Squawk code
Usage
Helicopter rescue flights
Federal police operational flights
Night low flying system military flights conducting terrain
following flights
Drop aircraft for parachutists
Aerobatic flights
Photogrammetric surveying flights
Squawk code
Usage
„Open Skies“ flights
VFR flights by civil aircraft in the identification zone
(border between Germany, Poland and the Czech Republic)
VFR flights by military aircraft between GND and FL 100
Search And Rescue missions (SAR)
VFR / IFR flight rule changes
Police operational flights
Police operational flights with residual light amplifier
Mode S transponder code
Military flights in the Night low flying system
VFR flights by civil aircraft (standard VFR code)
Hijacking (prohibited on VATSIM)
Radio failure
Emergency

paragraphs.content: If you've ever flown in real life or on VATSIM, then you've probably come across the transponder and entered 4 digits. But why is all this necessary?
There are two types of radar for monitoring air traffic:

· Primary radar: These are the huge, rotating radar antennas that detect so-called primary targets. According to a simple physical principle, the radar emits pulses that are reflected by aircraft. The radar can calculate the distance to the detected target based on the time between transmitting the pulse and receiving the reflection. The transponder therefore plays no role for this type of radar.

· Secondary radar: Secondary radar is used to obtain information about the aircraft's callsign and altitude in addition to its position. This is based on a question-and-answer principle. The radar antenna triggers the transponder via a signal, which then sends the code and altitude back to the ground station.

In the picture you can see the Deister radar system of German air traffic control (Deutsche Flugsicherung - DFS). The large curved part is the primary antenna, the small and flat area at the top is the secondary radar antenna.

The pilot can enter a four-digit transponder code into their transponder. The transponder has the digits 0-7 available for each digit. The system is therefore based on an octal code and offers 4096 different possibilities for a transponder code. Together with the clearance from air traffic control, the pilot receives the code to be set in the transponder. But why do we see a callsign on the radar

and not a four-digit number? Well, as soon as the controller has assigned the transponder code on the ground, this code is stored in the flight plan of this specific aircraft. As an example, let's assume that flight DLH414 is assigned the code 2301. If flight DLH414 now takes off, it emits code 2301 and is thus detected by a secondary radar. The secondary radar then sends the position, altitude and code 2301 to the air traffic control center. The radar system then checks the flight plan database and recognizes that code 2301 belongs to flight DLH414. The radar system therefore displays the callsign DLH414 and the corr ude to the controllers at the reported DLH98AD H A42 4 25 position, as shown in the following image.
Further information on the transponder can be found here.

As technology progressed, new transponders were introduced that were able to transmit many other parameters in addition to the altitude and the code, such as speed, heading, etc. With these transponders, which are called Mode S (Mode Sierra) transponders, the callsign is no longer transmitted via a four-digit code. Instead, the callsign is transmitted directly from the transponder to the secondary radar without the detour via code. Therefore, these flights no longer necessarily need different codes and usually receive Squawk 1000.
Mode S is now mandatory in Germany.
Further information on Mode S can be found here.
Fixed transponder codes are defined for certain flights in Germany. There are also international codes in the event of air emergencies.
Night low flying system military flights conducting terrain following flights
VFR flights by civil aircraft in the identification zone (border between Germany, Poland and the Czech Republic)
VFR flights by military aircraft between GND and FL 100
Police operational flights with residual light amplifier
Military flights in the Night low flying system
VFR flights by civil aircraft (standard VFR code)

analyzed_images.image_description: The image shows a radar tower with a large radar antenna mounted on top. The antenna is enclosed in a red and white protective structure. The tower itself is white and has a wide base that narrows as it rises. There is a tree visible on the right side of the image, and the sky is clear with a few clouds. The radar tower appears to be part of a larger installation, likely used for air traffic control or weather monitoring.

The image appears to be a screenshot of a display or interface, possibly related to aviation or navigation. It contains the text "DLH98AD H" in yellow, followed by "A42 ↓ 25" in white. There is a small grey square with a green line connected to the text. The background is dark, likely black. The text and symbols may represent specific codes or identifiers used in a technical or operational context.

metadata.abstract: The document 'Technical Knowledge' provides an in-depth look at the transponder and its role in air traffic control. It begins with an overview of radar basics, explaining the difference between primary and secondary radar systems. Primary radar detects aircraft by reflecting pulses off them, while secondary radar uses a transponder to obtain additional information such as callsign and altitude. The document details how transponder codes are assigned and correlated with flight plans, allowing controllers to see callsigns instead of just numerical codes. It also introduces Mode S transponders, which transmit more parameters directly, including the callsign, and are mandatory in Germany. The document lists various fixed transponder codes used for specific types of flights in Germany, such as rescue flights, police operations, and air emergencies. These codes help in identifying the nature of the flight and ensuring appropriate handling by air traffic control.

indexed_data.abstract: The document 'Technical Knowledge' provides an in-depth look at the transponder and its role in air traffic control. It begins with an overview of radar basics, explaining the difference between primary and secondary radar systems. Primary radar detects aircraft by reflecting pulses off them, while secondary radar uses a transponder to obtain additional information such as callsign and altitude. The document details how transponder codes are assigned and correlated with flight plans, allowing controllers to see callsigns instead of just numerical codes. It also introduces Mode S transponders, which transmit more parameters directly, including the callsign, and are mandatory in Germany. The document lists various fixed transponder codes used for specific types of flights in Germany, such as rescue flights, police operations, and air emergencies. These codes help in identifying the nature of the flight and ensuring appropriate handling by air traffic control.

Primary radar detects aircraft by reflecting pulses off them, while secondary radar uses a transponder to obtain additional information such as callsign and altitude. The document details how transponder codes are assigned and correlated with flight plans, allowing controllers to see callsigns instead of just numerical codes. It also introduces Mode S transponders, which transmit more parameters directly, including the callsign, and are mandatory in Germany. The document lists various fixed transponder codes used for specific types of flights in Germany, such as rescue flights, police operations, and air emergencies. These codes help in identifying the nature of the flight and ensuring appropriate handling by air traffic control.

indexed_data.content: and not a four-digit number? Well, as soon as the controller has assigned the transponder code on the ground, this code is stored in the flight plan of this specific aircraft. As an example, let's assume that flight DLH414 is assigned the code 2301. If flight DLH414 now takes off, it emits code 2301 and is thus detected by a secondary radar. The secondary radar then sends the position, altitude and code 2301 to the air traffic control center. The radar system then checks the flight plan database and recognizes that code 2301 belongs to flight DLH414. The radar system therefore displays the callsign DLH414 and the corr ude to the controllers at the reported DLH98AD H A42 4 25 position, as shown in the following image. Further information on the transponder can be found here. Mode S As technology progressed, new transponders were introduced that were able to transmit many other parameters in addition to the altitude and the code, such as speed, heading, etc. With these transponders, which are called Mode S (Mode Sierra) transponders, the callsign is no longer transmitted via a four-digit code. Instead, the callsign is transmitted directly from the transponder to the secondary radar without the detour via code. Therefore, these flights no longer necessarily need different codes and usually receive Squawk 1000. Mode S is now mandatory in Germany. Further information on Mode S can be found here. Special codes Fixed transponder codes are defined for certain flights in Germany. There are also international codes in the event of air emergencies. Squawk code Usage 0020 Helicopter rescue flights 0023 Federal police operational flights 0024 Night low flying system military flights conducting terrain following flights 0025 Drop aircraft for parachutists 0027 Aerobatic flights 0030 Photogrammetric surveying flights
